result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

9:39 AM - cases called - 21CM264, 21CM270, 22CF06 and 22CF108.  Defendant Khardea Francois Koptyra-Williams appeared by video, in custody from the Marathon County Jail.  Attorney Cana G Kohn appeared by video for Khardea Francois Koptyra-Williams.  Attorney Andrew R Polzin in court for State of Wisconsin.  State has complied with victim rights.  Court questions if there are any victims appearing that wish to be heard - no response.  Statement by Atty Kohn - in receipt of complaint - waive reading - requesting a signature bond - waives time limits.  Argument by State as to bond.  Court sets bond.  Court accepts wavier of time limits.

records.addlTxt:
1:31 PM - cases called - 21CM264 (tracking), 21CM270 and 22CF06.  Defendant Khardea Francois Koptyra-Williams appeared in court, in custody from the Lincoln County Jail.  Attorney Cana G Kohn appeared in court for Khardea Francois Koptyra-Williams.  Attorney Andrew R Polzin appeared in court for State of Wisconsin.  State has complied with victim rights.  Court questions if there are any victims appearing that wish to be heard - no response.  Statement by Atty Kohn - in receipt of complaints in 21CM270 and 22CF06 - waives reading - not guilty pleas in 21CM270.  Court accepts not guilty pleas in 21CM270.  Argument by State has to bond.  Response by Atty Kohn.  Court sets bond in 21CM270 and 22CF06.  Atty Kohn waive time limits for scheduling the preliminary hearing in 22CF06.  Court accepts waiver of time limits.
